Despite some worthy reform provisions, I ultimately opposed the proposed amendment Monday night that dealt with the Office of Congressional Ethics (OCE) being subject to oversight by the House Ethics Committee. As previous chairman of the bipartisan House Ethics Committee (a separate entity from OCE), I believe that all Members of Congress--regardless of party--should be held to the highest ethical standard. The proposed provision was not included in the House Rules for the 115th Congress that were adopted yesterday.

Today, Rep. Sam Johnson (TX-3) announced he plans to retire after the 115th Congress. Having served with Sam in the House, I know he is a man of character, a man of firm convictions, and a man of unwavering courage. Sam served his country as an Air Force pilot in both the Korean and Vietnam Wars, and he showed great fortitude and resilience as a prisoner of war for nearly seven years after being shot down while flying a mission over North Vietnam. Sam served as an inspirational leader to his fellow prisoners of war and his fellow colleagues in the House. While I'm saddened by his announcement, I am confident that he will continue to find ways to serve his community and country while inspiring those around him.

Today, I reintroduced a resolution that urges the Trump Administration to begin negotiations with the United Kingdom to establish a new bilateral trade agreement, the North Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (#NATIP).  The UK remains an ally who stands with us in NATO, in the G-8, in the World Trade Organization, and the United Nations. As they work through the process of implementing Brexit, we must take action to demonstrate our steadfast support. Congress and the current administration have a responsibility to foster the special relationship between the US and the UK, which has been built on shared history and values, a common language, and mutual trust.  The UK serves as one of the largest markets for US exports and the largest supplier of US imports. Additionally, over 900,000 American jobs are reliant on trade with British companies. The economic security of our two great nations is greatly dependent on our ability to maintain fair and regular trade relations, which is why I encourage the new administration to act on this proposal as soon as possible.

In my district over the weekend, I worked to assist a Syrian Christian family who, according to family members in #PA15 , held valid visas and were not refugees, yet were detained at the Philadelphia International Airport and then forced to leave the country within 3 hours as a result of the Executive Order. We also heard stories of interpreters, who put their lives at risk to assist our Armed Forces, being detained.   An important goal in governing is to enact policies to keep Americans safe, both at home and abroad; however, we must continue to protect innocent and vulnerable people abroad, many of whom are religious minorities, from persecution and potential annihilation. For these reasons, I have urged the Administration to halt enforcement of this executive order until a more thoughtful and deliberate policy can be instated.   http://www.mcall.com/news/nationworld/mc-syrian-family-allentown-stopped-philadelphia-airport-trump-immigration-ban-20170128-story.html

This afternoon, President Trump's national security adviser condemned Iran's most recent ballistic missile test launch. In doing so, the United States has sent a clear message that President Obama's Iranian appeasement project has come to an end. For too long, Iran and the Hezbollah terrorist organization that they finance have acted as a leading state sponsor of terror by meddling in Israel, Iraq, Yemen, Syria, and Lebanon. They have harassed U.S. naval vessels in the Persian Gulf, and have abducted and humiliated our sailors.   I continue to condemn Iran's ICBM tests, and have supported policy actions including the establishment of more robust missile defense programs and additional sanctions against Iran in the past. While Iran's continued provocations demonstrate that their leadership and military have not taken our warnings seriously thus far, it is my hope that they will now recognize that the United States and the international community will no longer stand for such disruptive violations.

Today, with my colleagues Congressman Donald M. Payne Jr. and Congressman Leonard Lance, I re-introduced #HR1017, the Removing Barriers to Colorectal Cancer Screening Act, which will make colorectal cancer screenings for seniors more accessible and affordable.  Under current law, seniors covered by Medicare aren't charged coinsurance for a screening colonoscopy. However, if the attending physician discovers a polyp and removes it (which is standard procedure), Medicare considers the procedure a "treatment" rather than a "screening." As a result, seniors are held responsible for covering the coinsurance, which can be anywhere from $100 to $300.  This bill would waive Medicare's cost-sharing requirement for screening colonoscopies, even if a polyp or tissue is removed. Colonoscopies are life-saving screening procedures, and we want to encourage more people to get them, not deter them because of high insurance costs.  This bill also has the support of Fight Colorectal Cancer and American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network - ACS CAN.

I recently cosponsored the bipartisan Russian Sanctions Review Act, which would require that Congress be consulted about, and approve of, any effort to remove the sanctions currently imposed on Russia. Vladimir Putin's aggressive actions in Ukraine and the repeated cyberattacks that Russia has carried out against U.S. government entities and individuals constitute a real threat to the democratic ideals that have long been held by the U.S. and our allies. Russia must demonstrate that they have the right to be considered for sanctions relief through clear and definitive actions such as ceasing their occupation of Crimea, their aggression in Ukraine, and their malevolent activities directed at our government and our nation's election system. Until that time comes, we must remain vigilant in our commitment to upholding the rule of law through any means necessary, including targeted sanctions.

The letter was sent to the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the U.S. Attorney General, and the Director of the FBI. It's imperative that federal agencies recognize the danger in these threats and work toward preventing them from ever being realized.

Last week, the Alliance of National Heritage Areas came together to celebrate their efforts in promoting National Heritage Areas (NHAs) across America and those in Congress who have supported these efforts. I was honored to join my colleague Rep. Paul D. Tonko in receiving the inaugural Heritage Champion Award.  NHAs are Congressionally recognized regions or areas that tell a nationally significant story representing our country's heritage. NHAs are operated by local organizations, and although they receive technical assistance from the National Park Service (NPS), they are not federally owned nor are they part of the NPS. Instead, NHAs help to tell the stories of local history in a national context, and advance economic, cultural, historic, environmental, and community development.  #PA15 is a part of both the Schuylkill River Heritage Area (which is home to Western Berks and the East Penn Valley in Berks County) and the Delaware & Lehigh National Heritage Corridor (which is home to the Ironton Rail-Trail, the Walnutport Canal & Locktenders House, and more). These NHAs showcase the natural beauty and history of #PA15, and it is important that these sites remain available for current and future generations. That's why I recently introduced the National Heritage Area Act. This important legislation would authorize a National Heritage Area System to better coordinate the establishment and management of NHAs across the country.  For more information about the NHAs in our districts, visit http://www.schuylkillriver.org/ and http://delawareandlehigh.org/map/.

The news out of Philadelphia this weekend regarding the acts of vandalism and desecration at the Mount Carmel Jewish cemetery is both troubling and disgraceful. Make no mistake, such actions are vile, cowardly, and hateful at their core. Such ugly attacks and threats against individuals or communities have no place in our society, and the solemn grounds of all faiths should be respected and honored. I am grateful for the steps taken by law enforcement personnel and by PA's Attorney General Josh Shapiro, who has offered his office's support to any investigations into this incident, as well as any additional threats made toward Jewish Community Centers and places of worship. I am also inspired by the broad public outcry against such heinous actions that have unfortunately become a disturbing trend in recent weeks. It is my hope that investigations being led by the Department of Homeland Security, the Attorney General of the United States, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation will also help to bring justice to the families and communities that have been subjected to these actions.

By providing our men and women in uniform with the resources and peace of mind they deserve at home we can generate a greater focus on the vital national security missions facing our nation and ensure that our military families are taken care of at home and abroad. The American health care system is in need of reform. The Affordable Care Act, which I voted against 7 years ago, has failed to live up to the promises of the previous Administration. Too many Americans have seen their health care costs rise, insurers are fleeing the marketplace, and businesses are struggling under the increased costs and regulations. In Pennsylvania the average 2017 premium increase for all individual market plans was 32%, and 68% of counties have only one or two insurers offering plans on the exchange. Clearly something must be done.  Over the past few weeks, I have diligently reviewed the American Health Care Act and recently proposed Amendments. I have spoken with constituents, leaders in the health care patient and provider community, Republican and Democrat Governors, Senators, the President and many others. After careful deliberation, I cannot support the bill and will oppose it. I believe this bill, in its current form, will lead to the loss of coverage and make insurances unaffordable for too many Americans, particularly for low-to-moderate income and older individuals. We have an important opportunity to enact reforms that will result in real health care transformation--bringing down costs and improving health outcomes. This legislation misses the mark.  I hope that the House can step back from this vote and arbitrary deadline to focus on getting health care reform done right to ensure that American families have access to affordable health care.

Health care reform should be about making care more affordable and accessible for American families.  Today's bill missed the mark.    It is time that we step back and focus on enacting durable, sustainable, and bipartisan reform of the American health care system that will lower costs, increase access and ensure quality care for all Americans.
Happy to be on with Eric Shawn today to discuss where health care reform should go from here. #HealthCareReform

This week marks #NationalLibraryWeek. For those that don't know, Benjamin Franklin founded the Library Company of Philadelphia in 1731, making it the first American public library, located right here in Pennsylvania. Recently, the Federal Communications Commission alerted consumers to be on the lookout for scam callers that attempt to get victims to say "yes" during the call. It's been reported that these scam callers have been using a recording of the response to authorize changes on the victim's utility or credit card account. Per complaints, these callers have impersonated representatives from organizations that provide a service and may sound familiar to the person receiving the call, such as a utility company or a mortgage lender.  If you, or someone you know, has been targeted by this scam, be sure to report the incident to the Better Business Bureau | US's Scam Tracker (https://www.bbb.org/scamtracker/us) and to the FCC's Consumer Complaint Center (https://consumercomplaints.fcc.gov/hc/en-us).  Additionally, you may wish to consider registering your phone to the state and national Do Not Call registry. This can be done by visiting the Pennsylvania Office of Attorney General's website (https://www.attorneygeneral.gov/Consumers/Do_Not_Call_List/Do_Not_Call_Enrollment/) and the Federal Trade Commission's website (https://www.donotcall.gov/register/reg.aspx). Both landlines and cell phone numbers can be included.

In addition to being Chairman of the House Appropriations #MILCONVA subcommittee, I am also proud to serve on the Transportation, Housing and Urban Development (THUD) subcommittee and the State and Foreign Operations (SFOPS) subcommittee. Today's #THUD hearing featured testimony from U.S. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) Ben Carson.  I stressed to Secretary Carson the importance of the HUD-Veterans Affairs Supportive Housing (HUD-VASH) program. HUD-VASH vouchers provide rental assistance for homeless veterans along with VA-provided case management and clinical services at nearby medical centers and community outreach clinics. This program has been instrumental in reducing veteran homelessness. I also raised concerns with the President's budget, which proposes eliminating funding for programs that are important to our communities, such as the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program and the Home Investment Partnerships Program (HOME). In #PA15, CDBG and HOME funding has been used as a catalyst to leverage private investment to make important affordable housing developments and other programs possible.  I also emphasized to the Secretary the importance of continued funding for the Housing Counseling Assistance Program, which supports counselors that provide pre- and post-purchase housing counseling to homeowners and tenants. This counseling helps struggling homeowners prevent foreclosure and stay in their homes and encourages smart financial decisions before making their first home purchase.

Attention College Students: Beginning in July, the U.S. State Department will once again accept applications for the Virtual Student Foreign Service (VSFS), an eight month remote internship program. Rather than having to move to Washington, D.C., VSFS allows students to work with the State Department or other federal agencies remotely from school, their apartments, or their dorm rooms. Students will then report to their supervisors by e-mail, phone, or video chat. This is a great opportunity for those who are interested in a D.C. internship, but who are unable to move to the city for the duration of a traditional internship.  In order to qualify, applicants must be U.S. citizens and either an undergraduate, graduate, or post-graduate student. Between July 2-26, applications for up to three projects may be submitted here: https://www.usajobs.gov/. Students will be notified of their status during the month of August, and for those chosen, projects will begin during the first two weeks of September.

Meet PFC Kenneth Happel, of Allentown. PFC Happel served in the 110th Field Artillery Battalion, 29th Infantry Division as part of the U.S. Army. The 29th Infantry Division was one of the most illustrious U.S. Army outfits of WWII. It was in combat from its successful assault of Omaha Beach on D-Day, June 6, 1944 to V-E Day and suffered more than 20,000 battle casualties in eleven months of combat. On July 18, 1944, the 29th Division liberated St. Lo, a critical crossroads city in Normandy, after 42 days of continuous combat from Omaha Beach. These were only two of six major campaigns in which the 29th Division participated. #PA15VeteransDay

Meet Michael O’Dell, an Allentown native, who served as part of the 3rd U.S. Infantry Regiment of the U.S. Army (the Old Guard), which consists of soldiers who guard the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. Training includes five grueling and progressive tests, along with reciting 35 pages of historical information error-free, before receiving the Tomb Guard Identification Badge. The Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor  in 1941 remains one of the darkest moments in our nation's history. America's shining beacon of freedom faced being extinguished during the attack that claimed 2,400 marine, sailor, soldier, and civilian lives, and the ensuing years of WWII. Yet, the attack was closely followed by an emphatic demonstration of America's unwavering resilience in the face of despair and destruction.  President Franklin Delano Roosevelt rallied a nation when he was tasked with consoling the rest of the country the following day. "Hostilities exist," he claimed. "there is no blinking at the fact that our people, our territory, and our interests are in grave danger." But he continued by assuring, "With confidence in our armed forces, with the unbounding determination of our people, we will gain the inevitable triumph - so help us God."  As we recognize the Pearl Harbor attack's 76th anniversary, let us never forget the ultimate price many in the Greatest Generation paid on this date. Further, may we always remain grateful for the safety and security that the men and women in our armed forces work to provide us daily.
